message.content:
Research the Premiere Pro UXP API for:
1. How to get audio from selected timeline clips
2. How to extract/export audio for processing
3. How to add labels/markers to clips
4. How to rename or tag clips with take numbers
5. Working with linked audio/video clips
6. Accessing clip metadata

Focus on what's actually possible in the UXP API for Premiere Pro.

Here are the search results for "Premiere Pro ExtendScript API timeline audio export clips":

## Overview

Premiere Pro's ExtendScript-based API allows for broad control of the entire application.(no content)ExtendScript can access and manipulate most project elements, including metadata, exporting and rendering options.

### Key Resources

The PProPanel sample exercises Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API: https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/tree/master/PProPanel.

### Exporting Audio from Timeline

For exporting selected audio clips from a sequence:

"Is there a way to get start and end points of the selected clip then export only that?" Yes; however, what will you do if more than one audio trackItem is selected? Briefly: Get the sequence selection, set the sequence in/out points to the beginning/end of the trackItem, then render.(no content)To export only audio, use an export preset (.epr file) that references an audio-only format. PProPanel shows how to render in PPro instead of AME.

### OMF Export for Audio

The Adobe-CEP samples include OMF export functionality for audio:

The API supports `app.project.exportOMF()` with parameters including sequence, output file path, OMF title, sample rate (48000 or 96000), bits per sample (16 or 24), audio encapsulated flag, audio file format (AIFF or WAV), trim audio files option, handle frames, and include pan flag.

### Timeline Clip Manipulation

You can create scripts that set the in/out point of the sequence and send it to Media Encoder. It iterates through all the clips in the sequence and does this for every one of them, essentially exporting the same sequence but with different in/out points.

### Important Notes

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.(no content)No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled. Any such changes will be reconsidered once Premiere Pro moves to UXP-based extensibility.

### Limitations

There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks.(no content)There is no API around merging clips.

Here's what I found about Adobe Premiere Pro UXP scripting API reference for clips, markers, and metadata:

## Adobe Premiere Pro UXP API Overview

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform).(no content)ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

### Key Documentation Resources

The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.

### What the UXP API Provides

Premiere APIs, also called DOM APIs, give you direct access to Premiere's document model. These APIs let you access and modify projects — sequences, tracks, clips, and markers; work with media — import files, manage project items; control playback — set in/out points, control the playhead; and apply effects.(no content)You can access sequences, tracks, clips, markers, project items, and application settings through the API.

### Markers API

The UXP API includes several marker-related functions:

The `getMarkers(markerOwnerObject: Sequence | ClipProjectItem)` method returns the Markers object for Sequence or ProjectItem. There's also:
- `createMoveMarkerAction(marker: Marker, tickTime: TickTime)` to move a marker to a new time value
- `createAddMarkerAction()` to add a new marker with parameters for name, marker type, start time, duration, and comments

### Metadata API

For metadata operations, the UXP API provides:

`createSetProjectMetadataAction(projectItem: ProjectItem, metadata: string, updatedFields: string[])` for setting project metadata, `createSetXMPMetadataAction(projectItem: ProjectItem, metadata: string)` for XMP metadata, `addPropertyToProjectMetadataSchema()` to add properties to the project metadata schema, and `getProjectColumnsMetadata(projectItem: ProjectItem)` to get project column metadata from a project item.

### Key Architecture Differences from ExtendScript

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread.(no content)For a smooth transition, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

### Versioning

The Premiere version (v25.6) determines which Premiere DOM APIs are available, while the UXP version (v8.1) determines which UXP Core APIs are available. Each Premiere release integrates a specific UXP version—for example, Premiere v25.6 includes UXP v8.1.

### Getting Started

You'll need the Premiere Pro BETA build (available through Creative Cloud Desktop) and the UXP Developer Tool (also available through Creative Cloud Desktop).

Here are the search results for Premiere Pro UXP API documentation related to timeline, clips, and audio:

## Key Findings

### Official Documentation
Premiere adds its own APIs on top of the base UXP functionality. This website provides documentation for both APIs. The official documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.

### API Capabilities
Premiere APIs, also called DOM APIs, give you direct access to Premiere's document model. These APIs let you access and modify projects — sequences, tracks, clips, and markers; work with media — import files, manage project items; control playback — set in/out points, control the playhead; and apply effects — add video and audio effects to clips.(no content)You can access sequences, tracks, clips, markers, project items, and application settings.

### Timeline and Clip Operations
The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin shows how to clone and remove track items. For moving clips between tracks, there's a `moveToTrack` method available through the QE DOM that accepts parameters for video track movement, audio track movement, timecode position, and whether to copy instead of move.

### UXP vs ExtendScript Transition
As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.(no content)UXP is the next generation of APIs, for Premiere v25.6 and beyond.

### Key Technical Differences
An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

### Sample Code & Resources
- The Adobe third-party sample panel is available in the premiere-api directory from the Git repository at github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples.
- The UXP sample plugin displays in Premiere Pro Beta. To see definitions, add TypeScript definitions to the .js file you're working in by copying types.d.ts to the root of the /html directory. You can then see and use TypeScript definitions for Premiere Pro's UXP APIs in Visual Studio Code.

### Community Discussion
Developers working with the Premiere Pro UXP API have found classes like Sequence, ClipProjectItem, and AudioClipTrackItem in the documentation for working with clips and sequences.

Based on my search for the Premiere Pro UXP API documentation on developer.adobe.com, here are the relevant results:

## Key Findings

### Sequence Class
The Sequence class includes functionality to "Clear TrackItem Selection" and "Create an action to clone the given sequence". The full documentation is available at: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/sequence/

### Premiere API Overview
The Premiere UXP API allows you to "access sequences, tracks, clips, markers, project items, and application settings."(no content)An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

### SequenceEditor Class
The SequenceEditor class allows you to "duplicate trackItem using an insert or overwrite edit method to a destination track. Target track and start time of trackItem is determined using an offset value from the original trackItem position."

### ProjectItemSelection Class
The ProjectItemSelection class lets you "get the project items that is represented by this selection".

### Accessing the API
Premiere Pro APIs (aka Document Object Model DOM or OMV) are used to create and modify the application document and content. The Premiere DOM is available only as a JavaScript module and should be retrieved on a need basis using require().

### UXP Platform
UXP allows you to build performant plugins with modern HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, and is the next generation of APIs for Premiere v25.6 and beyond.

For more detailed information about `getSelection`, `trackItems`, and audio-specific APIs, you may want to visit the Sequence class documentation directly at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/sequence/.

Based on my search results, I found information about the Premiere Pro UXP API's `createAddMarkerAction` method. Here's what I discovered:

## Premiere Pro UXP Markers API - `createAddMarkerAction`

The Markers class in Premiere Pro UXP returns the Markers object for Sequence or ProjectItem and allows you to move markers at new time values.

From the TypeScript definitions found in the Adobe documentation repository, the `createAddMarkerAction` method has the following signature:

```typescript
createAddMarkerAction(Name: string, markerType?: string, startTime?: TickTime, duration?: TickTime, comments?: string): Action
```

This method is used to add a new marker.

### Parameters:
- **Name** (string): The name of the marker (required)
- **markerType** (string, optional): The type of marker
- **startTime** (TickTime, optional): The start time of the marker
- **duration** (TickTime, optional): The duration of the marker
- **comments** (string, optional): Comments to attach to the marker

### Return Value:
The method returns an `Action` object.

### Additional Context

In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.(no content)UXP is the current extensibility standard for Adobe Creative Cloud applications, supported by Premiere (version 25.6), Photoshop, and InDesign.(no content)The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/

For the complete Markers API documentation, you can visit:
- https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/markers/

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the Premiere Pro UXP API for ClipProjectItem and accessing media paths for audio files:

## Premiere Pro UXP API - ClipProjectItem and Media Path Access

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere Pro and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.

### ClipProjectItem API

The ClipProjectItem API allows for attaching proxy or high resolution footage, or replacing footage via methods like `attachProxy()` and `changeMediaPath()`.(no content)ClipProjectItem returns true if Premiere Pro can change the path associated with this project item; otherwise, returns false. It also indicates whether it is possible to attach a proxy to this project item.

### Key Methods for Media Access

From the TypeScript definitions in the API:

`getMedia(): Promise<Media>` - Returns media associated with clipProjectItem.(no content)There's also a `cast(item: FolderItem | ClipProjectItem): ProjectItem` method to cast FolderItem or ClipProjectItem into ProjectItem.

### Project Item Types

The API includes various project item types: `TYPE_CLIP` for clips, `TYPE_BIN` for bins/folders, `TYPE_ROOT` for the root container, and `TYPE_FILE` for generic files.

### API Structure

Premiere APIs (also called DOM APIs) give you direct access to Premiere's document model. These APIs let you access and modify projects (sequences, tracks, clips, and markers), work with media (import files, manage project items), control playback, and apply video and audio effects to clips.

### Accessing the Premiere DOM

You can access the Premiere DOM via UXP, allowing you to open documents, modify them, run menu items, and more.(no content)An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous and blocked the UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread.

### Current Status

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.(no content)As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins.

For detailed documentation on ClipProjectItem and all available methods, you can visit the official Adobe developer documentation at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/clipprojectitem/

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP Sequence API methods for tracks and selections:

## Premiere Pro UXP Sequence API - Tracks and Selection

### Getting Selections

The `getSelection()` method returns a `Promise<TrackItemSelection>` that contains the current selection group of the sequence.(no content)A community member found that `getSelection()` returns currently-selected clips as an `Array` of `trackItems` and it works perfectly. Combined with `app.bind`, they were able to get real-time events of what the selected item is set to.

Example usage from the community:
```javascript
app.bind("onActiveSequenceSelectionChanged", function () {
    const selection = app.project.activeSequence.getSelection();
```

### Getting Video and Audio Tracks

The API provides methods to get individual tracks by index:
- `getVideoTrack(trackIndex: number): Promise<VideoTrack>` - Get video track from track index
- `getAudioTrack(trackIndex: number): Promise<AudioTrack>` - Get audio track from track index
- `getCaptionTrack(trackIndex: number): Promise<CaptionTrack>` - Get caption track from track index

### Accessing Track Items

Track items can be accessed via paths like:
- `app.project.sequences[index].audioTracks[index].clips[index]`
- `app.project.sequences[index].videoTracks[index].clips[index]`

The TrackItem object represents an item on a video or audio track within a Sequence object.

### TrackItemSelection Type

The `TrackItemSelection` type includes methods for modifying selections:
- `addItem(trackItem: object, skipDuplicateCheck?: boolean): boolean` - Add a track item to this selection
- `removeItem(trackItem: object): boolean` - Remove a track item from the selection

### Key UXP vs ExtendScript Difference

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous and blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread. However, for a smooth transition, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

### Current Status

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported and planned to remain so through September 2026.

For official documentation, you can visit the [Adobe Premiere Pro UXP API documentation](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/).

Based on my search results, I found comprehensive information about the Premiere Pro UXP TrackItem and AudioClipTrackItem properties and methods. Here's what I found:

## Premiere Pro UXP - AudioClipTrackItem Properties & Methods

### AudioClipTrackItem Static Constants
The AudioClipTrackItemStatic type includes the following track item type constants:
- `TRACKITEMTYPE_EMPTY` - Empty Track Item Type
- `TRACKITEMTYPE_CLIP` - Clip Track Item Type
- `TRACKITEMTYPE_TRANSITION` - Transition Track Item Type
- `TRACKITEMTYPE_PREVIEW` - Preview Track Item Type
- `TRACKITEMTYPE_FEEDBACK` - Feedback Track Item Type

### AudioClipTrackItem Methods for Clip Name & Properties
The AudioClipTrackItem type includes these key methods:
- `getMatchName(): Promise<string>` - Returns the value of internal matchname for this trackItem
- `getName(): Promise<string>` - Returns the display name for trackItem
- `getIsSelected(): Promise<boolean>` - Returns if trackItem is selected or not

### Getting TrackItems from Audio Tracks
`getTrackItems(trackItemType: Constants.TrackItemType, includeEmptyTrackItems: boolean): AudioClipTrackItem[]` - Returns array of AudioClipTrackItem from the track item type.

### Additional TrackItem Methods (from ExtendScript, similar patterns in UXP)
From the ExtendScript API documentation, TrackItem objects have these properties:

- The TrackItem object represents an item on a video or audio track, within a Sequence object. It includes components associated with the trackItem, which can include intrinsic transformations, as well as video and audio effects.

- The name of the track item is available as a String (read/write in ExtendScript).

- `isSelected()` - Retrieves the current selection state of the trackItem. Returns true if trackItem is selected; false if not.

### UXP API Design Note
For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited. It is worth noting that they are, in the background, asynchronous in nature. Through the app object, you can access the rest of Premiere's objects and methods.

### Related SequenceEditor Methods
`createCloneTrackItemAction(trackItem: VideoClipTrackItem | AudioClipTrackItem, timeOffset: TickTime, videoTrackVerticalOffset: number, audioTrackVerticalOffset: number, alignToVideo: boolean, isInsert: boolean): Action` - Duplicates trackItem using an insert or overwrite edit method to a destination track. Target track and start time of trackItem is determined using an offset value from the original trackItem position.

### Documentation Resources
- The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

- The TrackItem object represents an item on a video or audio track, within a Sequence object. It includes components associated with the trackItem, which can include intrinsic transformations, as well as video and audio effects.

- The name of the track item is available as a String (read/write in ExtendScript).

- `isSelected()` - Retrieves the current selection state of the trackItem. Returns true if trackItem is selected; false if not.

### UXP API Design Note
For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited. It is worth noting that they are, in the background, asynchronous in nature. Through the app object, you can access the rest of Premiere's objects and methods.

### Related SequenceEditor Methods
`createCloneTrackItemAction(trackItem: VideoClipTrackItem | AudioClipTrackItem, timeOffset: TickTime, videoTrackVerticalOffset: number, audioTrackVerticalOffset: number, alignToVideo: boolean, isInsert: boolean): Action` - Duplicates trackItem using an insert or overwrite edit method to a destination track. Target track and start time of trackItem is determined using an offset value from the original trackItem position.

### Documentation Resources
- The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro's ProjectItem and getting media file paths:

## ProjectItem.getMediaPath() Method

The `getMediaPath()` method returns the path associated with the project item's media, as a String.

### Usage
The method is called using:
```javascript
app.project.rootItem.children[index].getMediaPath()
```

### Important Limitations

This only works for atomic media; this call cannot provide meaningful paths for media which has no actual path (which will be the case for any media generated by synthetic importers, like Premiere Pro's own Universal Counting Leader). Also, for image sequences, only the path to the first image in the sequence will be returned.(no content)Additionally, `getMediaPath()` returns undefined when your current item is a folder, sequence or title.

### Related Methods

- `canChangeMediaPath()` - Returns true if Premiere Pro can change the path associated with this project item; otherwise, returns false.
- `changeMediaPath(newPath)` - Updates the project item to point to a new media path.
- `findItemsMatchingMediaPath(pathToMatch, ignoreSubClips)` - Returns an array of project items, all of which reference the same media path.

### Mac-Specific Issue

There's a known issue where different paths are returned using `projectItem.getMediaPath()` on Mac, having an extra prefix "/Volumes/Macintosh HD" in the file path when imported from the media browser panel.

## UXP API Notes

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.(no content)In UXP, ProjectItems are somewhat generic objects that simply provide the starting point to accessing the specific attributes of each type of item. For example, ClipProjectItems can do things that FolderItems can't, and vice versa. So when you use `.getItems()` to get the contents of a folder, all contained items get listed as ProjectItems, and then you must inspect these items to step into further functionality for each one.(no content)The UXP API currently uses `.cast()` for this purpose.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP export, audio render, sequence, AME (Adobe Media Encoder), and the encoder API:

## Premiere Pro UXP Extensibility

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform).(no content)ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.(no content)UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications, powered by a modern JavaScript engine that offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.

## Encoder API for AME (Adobe Media Encoder)

The UXP API provides several export and encoding methods:

### Export Types (Constants)
The API includes export type constants: `EXPORT_QUEUE_TO_AME` (used to queue an export job into the Adobe Media Encoder export queue), `EXPORT_QUEUE_TO_APP` (used to queue an export job into the app export queue), and `EXPORT_IMMEDIATELY` (used to immediately export an object).

### Render Events
The API broadcasts events including `EVENT_RENDER_COMPLETE` (when AME is finished rendering), `EVENT_RENDER_ERROR` (when AME gives back an error message), `EVENT_RENDER_CANCEL` (when an AME job is canceled), `EVENT_RENDER_QUEUE` (when an AME job is queued), and `EVENT_RENDER_PROGRESS` (when AME job is rendering).

### Key Methods

**exportSequence:**
`exportSequence(sequence: Sequence, exportType: Constants.ExportType, outputFile?: string, presetFile?: string, exportFull?: boolean): Promise<boolean>` - Exports a sequence. If no output file and preset is specified, the sequence will be exported with the applied export settings or standard export rules will be applied.

**encodeProjectItem:**
`encodeProjectItem(clipProjectItem: ClipProjectItem, outputFile: string, presetFile: string, workArea?: number, removeUponCompletion?: boolean, startQueueImmediately?: boolean): Promise<boolean>` - Encodes input clipProjectItem in AME.

**encodeFile:**
`encodeFile(filePath: string, outputFile: string, presetFile: string, inPoint: TickTime, outPoint: TickTime, workArea?: number, removeUponCompletion?: boolean, startQueueImmediately?: boolean): Promise<boolean>` - Encodes input media file in AME. The `isAMEInstalled` property can check if AME is installed.

**exportSequenceFrame:**
`exportSequenceFrame(sequence: Sequence, time: TickTime, filename: string, filepath: string, width: number, height: number): Promise<boolean>` - Exports from a sequence. Supported formats are bmp, dpx, gif, jpg, exr, png, tga and tif.

## Async vs Sync Behavior

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous and blocked the UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

## Resources

- The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.
- Sample plugins are available on GitHub with instructions for developing UXP plugins within Premiere Pro (as of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins).

## Key Findings

### UXP Method for Renaming TrackItems

In Premiere Pro UXP, there is a `createSetNameAction(inName: string): Action` method that "Returns an action that renames the trackItem." This is the method you would use to rename clips on the timeline.

### Current Limitations

Some developers have noted that they have old CEP scripts for renaming clips on the timeline, but they can't find anything suggesting Premiere UXP currently supports renaming videotrack clip items.(no content)For some use cases, simply renaming the project item associated with the clip will not work because some clips may share the same source footage.

### TrackItem Properties (ExtendScript Reference)

In the ExtendScript API, the name of the track item is a "String; read/write" property.

### UXP Transition and Platform Status

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

### Metadata

The UXP Metadata class allows you to "Add name and label property to project metadata schema" and "Get set project metadata action."

### Additional Context

Developers have also expressed difficulty figuring out if UXP can move projectItems to a specific bin, rename a projectItem (specifically, a sequence), or duplicate a sequence and set a custom name.

The `createSetNameAction` method from the UXP API appears to be the intended way to rename trackItems, though some developers have reported difficulties finding full support for this functionality in practice.

In the ExtendScript API, the name of the track item is a "String; read/write" property.

### UXP Transition and Platform Status

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

### Metadata

The UXP Metadata class allows you to "Add name and label property to project metadata schema" and "Get set project metadata action."

### Additional Context

Developers have also expressed difficulty figuring out if UXP can move projectItems to a specific bin, rename a projectItem (specifically, a sequence), or duplicate a sequence and set a custom name.

The `createSetNameAction` method from the UXP API appears to be the intended way to rename trackItems, though some developers have reported difficulties finding full support for this functionality in practice.

Based on the search results, here's what I found regarding Premiere Pro UXP Metadata class and setProjectMetadataAction with XMP:

## Key Findings

### UXP Metadata Class in Premiere Pro
The Metadata class in Premiere Pro UXP API allows you to "Add name and label property to project metadata schema" and "Get set project metadata action".

### XMP Module in UXP
The XMP module in UXP offers JavaScript access to the Adobe XMP Core and XMP Files libraries. To use the XMP objects, you must import the XMP module.(no content)The XMPFile.getXMP() method creates an XMPMeta object, which you can use to examine or modify the properties and their values. You can then use XMPFile.putXMP() to write the modified metadata back to the file.(no content)The XMPMeta object is the primary means of access to the namespaces and properties of an XMP metadata packet. Through this object, you can create and delete namespaces and properties, and examine and modify property values.

### UXP Transition
As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

### Project Metadata with setProjectMetadata
From the community discussion, the issue with setProjectMetadata was "not passing the array of modified values." The setProjectMetadata function needs a second argument, which wasn't clearly documented.

ColumnID and ColumnPath can be used to modify that column via the method setProjectMetadata() or setXMPMetadata().

### XMP Overview
Adobe's XMP (Extensible Metadata Platform) is a metadata standard developed by Adobe Systems. It allows users to embed descriptive, rights, and other metadata into digital files. XMP is extensible and customizable, supporting various types of information and user-defined schemas.

For detailed documentation on the UXP Metadata class and setProjectMetadataAction specifically, you may want to refer directly to the Adobe Developer documentation at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/metadata/.

content.text:
Based on my research, here is a comprehensive summary of what is possible with the Premiere Pro UXP API for your use cases:

---

## Premiere Pro UXP API Research Summary

### 1. Getting Audio from Selected Timeline Clips

**Available Methods:**
- `app.project.activeSequence.getSelection()` - Returns `Promise<TrackItemSelection>` with currently selected clips
- `sequence.getAudioTrack(trackIndex)` - Returns `Promise<AudioTrack>` for specific audio track
- `audioTrack.getTrackItems(trackItemType, includeEmptyTrackItems)` - Returns `AudioClipTrackItem[]`

**Event Binding:**
```javascript
app.bind("onActiveSequenceSelectionChanged", function () {
    const selection = app.project.activeSequence.getSelection();
    // selection contains array of trackItems
});
```

**Getting Source Media Path:**
- `projectItem.getMediaPath()` - Returns the file path to the source media
- Only works for atomic media (not synthetic/generated clips)
- On Mac, may return path with extra "/Volumes/Macintosh HD" prefix

---

### 2. Extracting/Exporting Audio for Processing

**Export Methods:**
- `Encoder.exportSequence(sequence, exportType, outputFile, presetFile, exportFull)` - Export full sequence
- `Encoder.encodeProjectItem(clipProjectItem, outputFile, presetFile, ...)` - Encode specific clip via AME
- `Encoder.encodeFile(filePath, outputFile, presetFile, inPoint, outPoint, ...)` - Encode file with in/out points

**Export Type Constants:**
- `EXPORT_QUEUE_TO_AME` - Queue to Adobe Media Encoder
- `EXPORT_QUEUE_TO_APP` - Queue to app export queue
- `EXPORT_IMMEDIATELY` - Export immediately

**Audio-Only Export:**
Use an export preset (.epr file) configured for audio-only format (WAV, AIFF, etc.)

**Render Events:**
- `EVENT_RENDER_COMPLETE`, `EVENT_RENDER_ERROR`, `EVENT_RENDER_CANCEL`, `EVENT_RENDER_PROGRESS`

**Limitation:** No direct API to extract raw audio data in memory. You must export to file using presets.

---

### 3. Adding Labels/Markers to Clips

**Markers API:**
- `Metadata.getMarkers(markerOwnerObject)` - Get markers for Sequence or ClipProjectItem
- `markers.createAddMarkerAction(name, markerType, startTime, duration, comments)` - Add a marker
- `markers.createMoveMarkerAction(marker, tickTime)` - Move existing marker

**Example:**
```javascript
const markers = ppro.Metadata.getMarkers(sequence);
const action = markers.createAddMarkerAction(
    "Take 1",           // name
    "Comment",          // markerType
    startTickTime,      // startTime
    durationTickTime,   // duration
    "Auto-detected take" // comments
);
await action.execute();
```

---

### 4. Renaming or Tagging Clips with Take Numbers

**TrackItem Renaming:**
- `trackItem.createSetNameAction(inName)` - Returns Action to rename the trackItem
- `trackItem.getName()` - Get current display name
- `trackItem.getMatchName()` - Get internal match name

**Metadata for Tagging:**
- `Metadata.createSetProjectMetadataAction(projectItem, metadata, updatedFields)` - Set project metadata
- `Metadata.createSetXMPMetadataAction(projectItem, metadata)` - Set XMP metadata
- `Metadata.addPropertyToProjectMetadataSchema(name, label, type)` - Add custom metadata field
- `Metadata.getProjectColumnsMetadata(projectItem)` - Get existing metadata

**XMP Module:**
```javascript
const xmp = require('uxp').xmp;
// Access XMPMeta and XMPFile for reading/writing XMP metadata
```

**Note:** Some developers report difficulty getting `createSetNameAction` to work for timeline clips. Renaming the source ProjectItem may propagate to all clips using that source.

---

### 5. Working with Linked Audio/Video Clips

**Current Status:** No dedicated `getLinkedTrackItems()` method found in the UXP API.

**Available Methods:**
- `clipProjectItem.isMergedClip()` - Check if clip is a merged clip
- `clipProjectItem.isMulticamClip()` - Check if clip is multicam

**Workaround Approach:**
1. Get selection from both video and audio tracks
2. Match clips by their source `projectItem` reference or time position
3. Video and audio from the same source file typically share the same `ClipProjectItem`

---

### 6. Accessing Clip Metadata

**Project Metadata:**
- `Metadata.getProjectColumnsMetadata(projectItem)` - Get metadata columns
- `Metadata.createSetProjectMetadataAction(projectItem, metadata, updatedFields)`

**XMP Metadata:**
- `Metadata.createSetXMPMetadataAction(projectItem, metadata)`
- Use UXP's `require('uxp').xmp` module for full XMP read/write

**Custom Schema:**
- `Metadata.addPropertyToProjectMetadataSchema(name, label, type)` - Add custom fields

**Media Info:**
- `clipProjectItem.getMedia()` - Returns `Promise<Media>` with media properties
- `projectItem.getMediaPath()` - Source file path

---

## Key API Patterns

**Action Pattern:** Many methods return an `Action` object that must be executed:
```javascript
const action = markers.createAddMarkerAction("Name", ...);
await action.execute();
```

**Async Nature:** UXP calls are asynchronous (unlike ExtendScript), but property access is synchronous for compatibility.

**Casting:** Use `ProjectItem.cast(item)` to convert between FolderItem/ClipProjectItem types.

---

## Current Limitations

1. **No direct audio buffer access** - Cannot read raw audio samples; must export to file
2. **No vertical clip movement** - Cannot programmatically move clips between tracks
3. **No clip merging API** - Cannot merge clips via API
4. **Linked clips** - No explicit API for linked audio/video relationships
5. **Beta status** - As of December 2025, UXP plugins only work in Premiere Pro Beta

---

## Sources

- [Adobe Premiere Pro UXP Documentation](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/)
- [Premiere API Reference](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/)
- [Sequence Class](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/sequence/)
- [ClipProjectItem Class](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/clipprojectitem/)
- [Markers Class](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/markers/)
- [Metadata Class](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/metadata/)
- [UXP TypeScript Definitions](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro/blob/main/src/pages/ppro_reference/types.d.ts)
- [UXP Sample Plugins](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples)
- [Premiere Pro Scripting Guide (ExtendScript)](https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/)
- [Adobe Developer Forums](https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/)
